column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span

#Text=On our way from Khopong, along the ancient river-bed which forms the pathway to Boatlanama, I found a species of cactus, being the third I have seen in the country, namely, one in the colony with a bright red flower, one at Lake Ngami, the flower of which was liver-colored, and the present one, flower unknown.

#Text=That the plant is uncommon may be inferred from the fact that the Bakwains find so much difficulty in recognizing the plant again after having once seen it, that they believe it has the power of changing its locality.
#Text=On the 21st of January we reached the wells of Boatlanama, and found them for the first time empty.
#Text=Lopepe, which I had formerly seen a stream running from a large reedy pool, was also dry.
#Text=The hot salt spring of Serinane, east of Lopepe, being undrinkable, we pushed on to Mashue for its delicious waters.
#Text=In traveling through this country, the olfactory nerves are frequently excited by a strong disagreeable odor.
#Text=This is caused by a large jet-black ant named "Leshonya".
#Text=It is nearly an inch in length, and emits a pungent smell when alarmed, in the same manner as the skunk.
#Text=The scent must be as volatile as ether, for, on irritating the insect with a stick six feet long, the odor is instantly perceptible.
#Text=Occasionally we lighted upon land tortoises, which, with their unlaid eggs, make a very agreeable dish.
#Text=We saw many of their trails leading to the salt fountain; they must have come great distances for this health-giving article.
#Text=In lieu thereof they often devour wood-ashes.
#Text=It is wonderful how this reptile holds its place in the country.
#Text=When seen, it never escapes.
#Text=The young are taken for the sake of their shells; these are made into boxes, which, filled with sweet-smelling roots, the women hang around their persons.
#Text=When older it is used as food, and the shell converted into a rude basin to hold food or water.
#Text=It owes its continuance neither to speed nor cunning.

#Text=Its color, yellow and dark brown, is well adapted, by its similarity to the surrounding grass and brushwood, to render it indistinguishable; and, though it makes an awkward attempt to run on the approach of man, its trust is in its bony covering, from which even the teeth of a hyaena glance off foiled.

#Text=When this long-lived creature is about to deposit her eggs, she lets herself into the ground by throwing the earth up round her shell, until only the top is visible; then covering up the eggs, she leaves them until the rains begin to fall and the fresh herbage appears; the young ones then come out, their shells still quite soft, and, unattended by their dam, begin the world for themselves.
#Text=Their food is tender grass and a plant named thotona, and they frequently resort to heaps of ashes and places containing efflorescence of the nitrates for the salts these contain.
